body:
POLITICO
Intelligence and analysis on lobbying
By Tarini Parti
8/10/15 1:59 PM EDT
With Anna Palmer and Aaron Mak 
LATEST REGISTRATIONS — ELLIOTT MANAGEMENT ADDS FORBES-TATE: Hedge fund Elliott Management Corporation, which is run by GOP megadonor Paul Singer, has brought on Forbes-Tate to lobby on issues related to financial services. The firm’s Daniel Tate, Jeff Strunk, Frank Steinberg, Libby Greer and Jeff Sadosky will be lobbying on behalf of the hedge fund. Elliott Management has significantly decreased its spending on lobbying in recent years. It spent $230,000 on lobbying the federal government last year and has spent only $20,000 so far this year. The firm has Malkin & Ross on retainer.
Story Continued Below
COVINGTON CELEBRATES EDUCATION BILL PASSAGE: Lobbyists at Covington & Burling who pushed for the passage of Need-Based Educational Aid Act of 2015, which President Barack Obama signed into law last week, highlighted the legislation as a rare example of Congress functioning the way it’s intended to in an interview with PI. The firm’s Richard Hertling and Aaron Cooper worked on behalf of American Council on Education and the 568 Presidents’ Group to extend an exemption from federal anti-trust laws for private universities giving students need-based aid from the universities’ own funds. The exemption was due to expire on Sept. 30. “When congress is working together, they can work together in a bipartisan and bicameral way. The process on this legislation really emulates that and shows that things can still happen on Capitol Hill,” Cooper said.
SCALISE GETTING THE CONVENIENCE STORE EXPERIENCE: House Majority Whip Steve Scalise will work behind the counter at On the Run (Lard Oil Company) in Hammond, La., Tuesday as part of the National Association of Convenience Stores' "In Store" project. NACS has organized more than a dozen events in 2015 with lawmakers so they can "experience firsthand the community experience that takes place at their local convenience stores," according to the group. “Convenience stores are the anchor of communities across the country, and they are also where community conversations take place,” said Henry Armour, NACS president and CEO. “More than half of the country visits a convenience store on a daily basis, whether to buy fuel, use the ATM, wash their cars or quickly buy snacks, drinks or meals. The NACS In Store program gives elected officials a perfect opportunity to experience how these stores serve the public in their home districts.”
GOOD MONDAY AFTERNOON, where it’s been 67 years since "Candid Camera" with Allen Funt debuted on television. Hope everyone had a great weekend! Don’t forget to send your tips, news and gossip to tparti@politico.com.

NEW REFORM GROUP PARTNERS WITH PRO-CLINTON PAC: End Citizens United PAC, a new political action committee, is partnering with Ready PAC — previously known as Ready for Hillary — to back candidates who support campaign finance reform. The group is renting the pro-Clinton super PAC’s list and has been able to raise over $2 million so far. The political action committee’s ultimate goal is to pass a constitutional amendment to overturn the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision, but in the meantime, the group will also advocate for other campaign finance reform measures.
It plans to create a super PAC arm next year and spend between $25 million and $30 million in the 2016 election cycle. Richard Carbo, spokesman for the group, told PI that they are approaching the issue differently than other reform groups and believe the partnership with Ready PAC provides them legitimacy in an early stage. “We're bringing a different approach and a different style, but the more the merrier,” Carbo said. “We are just doing things a little bit differently and engaging some of the grassroots activists who are involved in the issue. The staff here has also been battle-tested in campaigns.”
The group’s senior advisers are Valerie Martin, who worked for Sen. Claire McCaskill’s 2006 campaign, and Reed Adamson, who worked for Rep. Brad Schneider during the 2012 cycle.
SPINA TO COMMODITY FUTURES TRADING COMMISSION: Christopher Spina, most recently communications director for the House Committee on Financial Services, is leaving the hill to serve as senior adviser for public affairs with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, he told friends and colleagues in an email.
NEW DEMS PLAN ‘ASSERTIVE’ NEW PRESENCE: Via POLITICO’s Lauren French, “In the hierarchy of the House, moderate Democrats — a minority in a party already deep in the minority — should be totally powerless. But a group of pro-business Democrats, who allied with President Barack Obama and Republicans to pass landmark trade legislation, are angling to cut more deals with the GOP and White House as a way to assert themselves — and force the Democratic Caucus to the center. Led by Rep. Ron Kind of Wisconsin, the New Democrat Coalition of some 50 members sees opportunities this fall on taxes, trade, Medicare and government spending. Those are all areas where House Republicans have struggled to fashion 218-vote majorities from within their own party, with a cadre of restive conservatives often rejecting leadership’s compromises with Senate Democrats and Obama.” Full story: http://politi.co/1EjEQil
ELSEWHERE IN THE INFLUENCE WORLD:
INVESTMENT FIRM TO HOLD RUBIO EVENT: Sen. Marco Rubio is scheduled to attend a fundraiser at the Bellevue investment firm Steelhead Partners in Washington state on Monday evening, reports Jim Brunner of The Seattle Times. http://bit.ly/1P1jHza
JEB GETS HELP FROM NEXTERA INC. NextEra Energy Inc., the largest Florida corporate donor to a super PAC, is backing former Gov. Jeb Bush's presidential run, reports Jack Gillum and Ronnie Greene of The Associated Press. http://bit.ly/1J69nHU

By MICHAEL KRUSE and  MANU RAJU

title: Elliott Management adds Forbes-Tate — Covington celebrates education bill passage — Scalise getting the convenience store experience
